importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the CNN article covering NFL Week 7 of the 2025 season, highlighting dramatic comebacks, record-breaking performances, and team benchings.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This time frame covers the first seven weeks of the 2025 NFL season, during which 26 lead changes occurred in the final two minutes of regulation — the most in NFL history for that span — indicating a season marked by unpredictability and dramatic reversals.

keyTakeAways: The 2025 NFL season has shown increasing unpredictability, with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation through Week 7 — the most ever in NFL history for that span.
The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter, becoming the first team since 2007 to reverse an 18-point lead after the first three quarters.

Second-year QB Bo Nix led a dramatic fourth-quarter comeback against the New York Giants, throwing 16-of-25 for 174 yards and two touchdowns and rushing for two scores, culminating in a game-winning field goal as time expired.

Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 win over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in a single game.

The Miami Dolphins and New York Jets both suffered significant losses, with Tua Tagovailoa and Justin Fields benched due to poor performances — Tagovailoa throwing three picks in a 31-6 loss to the Browns, and Fields going 6-of-12 for 46 yards in the first half before being replaced by Tyrod Taylor.
The New York Jets' head coach Aaron Glenn made a mid-game benching decision for Justin Fields, citing the need for a 'spark' and acknowledging the team's offensive struggles.
The Green Bay Packers defeated the Arizona Cardinals in a dramatic finish, with Micah Parsons (traded from Dallas) recording a crucial sack on Arizona’s final drive.
The Denver Broncos are now the first team in NFL history to overcome a 161-0 record since 2007 of teams that shut out opponents and lead by 18 points or more after three quarters.

Drake Maye’s performance marked a pivotal moment for the New England Patriots, signaling a potential new era under head coach Mike Vrabel, who had previously been fired by the Patriots and now has a victory in his first game against them.

namedEntities.name: Denver Broncos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter, becoming the first team since 2007 to reverse a 18-point lead after the first three quarters and breaking a 161-0 record of such shutouts with a lead in the first three quarters.

namedEntities.name: New York Giants
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The New York Giants were outscored in the fourth quarter by the Denver Broncos, leading to a dramatic 33-32 comeback win, marking one of the most improbable comebacks in NFL history.

namedEntities.name: Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Packers defeated the Arizona Cardinals in the final minutes, scoring two touchdowns in the fourth quarter and forcing a crucial turnover on downs, demonstrating resilience and strong defensive play, particularly by Micah Parsons.

namedEntities.name: New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Patriots saw a breakout performance from quarterback Drake Maye, who broke Tom Brady’s franchise record in completion percentage and set a Super Bowl-era milestone in a single game, signaling a potential new era under head coach Mike Vrabel.

namedEntities.name: Tennessee Titans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Titans lost to the New England Patriots in a game where Drake Maye recorded historic stats, including a 91.3% completion rate and a 200+ yard passing performance with over 50 yards rushing.

namedEntities.name: Miami Dolphins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dolphins lost to the Cleveland Browns 31-6, with quarterback Tua Tagovailoa throwing three interceptions — including one returned for a touchdown — leading to his immediate benching in favor of rookie Quinn Ewers.

namedEntities.name: New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Jets fell 13-6 to the Carolina Panthers, with quarterback Justin Fields performing poorly in the first half, leading to his benching at halftime in favor of Tyrod Taylor.

namedEntities.name: Carolina Panthers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Panthers defeated the New York Jets, with quarterback Bryce Young injured during the game, yet the team managed to secure a first win on the road and highlighted the vulnerability of the Jets' offense.

namedEntities.name: Cleveland Browns
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Browns defeated the Miami Dolphins 31-6, a game that saw the Dolphins’ quarterback Tua Tagovailoa benched due to poor performance and turnovers.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Rams
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Rams played in London, UK, and won against the Jacksonville Jaguars 35-7, contributing to the narrative of unpredictability and dramatic finishes in Week 7.

namedEntities.name: Chicago Bears
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bears defeated the New Orleans Saints 26-14, contributing to a broader narrative of offensive momentum and team success in the early season.

namedEntities.name: Kansas City Chiefs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Chiefs defeated the Las Vegas Raiders 31-0, showcasing a dominant performance and contributing to the theme of high-scoring, one-sided games in Week 7.

namedEntities.name: Minnesota Vikings
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Vikings lost to the Philadelphia Eagles 22-28, highlighting a dramatic finish in the NFC and contributing to the narrative of unpredictable results.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Chargers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Chargers lost to the Indianapolis Colts 24-38, illustrating a late-game collapse and reinforcing the theme of dramatic comebacks and collapses.

namedEntities.name: Arizona Cardinals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Cardinals lost to the Green Bay Packers 23-27, with backup quarterback Jacoby Brissett struggling on offense and being disrupted by Micah Parsons' defensive dominance.

namedEntities.name: Dallas Cowboys
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Cowboys defeated the Washington Commanders 44-22, showing a dominant performance and contributing to the trend of high-scoring games and offensive strength.

namedEntities.name: San Francisco 49ers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 49ers defeated the Atlanta Falcons 20-10, marking a strong performance and part of the broader trend of team success and defensive efficiency.

namedEntities.name: Bo Nix
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bo Nix led the Denver Broncos in a historic comeback, throwing 16-of-25 for 174 yards and two touchdowns, rushing for two scores, and setting up a game-winning field goal as time expired.

namedEntities.name: Drake Maye
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate in a game against the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in a single game.

namedEntities.name: Tua Tagovailoa
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tua Tagovailoa had a poor performance against the Cleveland Browns, throwing three interceptions — one returned for a touchdown — leading to his immediate benching in favor of rookie Quinn Ewers.

namedEntities.name: Justin Fields
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Justin Fields struggled in the first half against the Carolina Panthers, leading to his benching at halftime in favor of Tyrod Taylor, highlighting offensive instability.

namedEntities.name: Micah Parsons
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Micah Parsons, traded from the Dallas Cowboys to Green Bay, recorded a crucial sack on Arizona’s final drive and was a dominant defensive force throughout the game, leading to a Packers win.

namedEntities.name: Mike Vrabel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mike Vrabel coached the New England Patriots in a win against the Tennessee Titans, marking his first victory in a game against the Patriots since being fired by them in January 2024, and signaling a turning point in the franchise’s quarterback development.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Glenn
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Aaron Glenn, the head coach of the New York Jets, made a mid-game benching decision for quarterback Justin Fields, citing the need for a 'spark' and acknowledging offensive struggles.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season, the league experienced unprecedented unpredictability with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation — the most in NFL history. The Denver Broncos made history by overcoming a 19-point deficit in the fourth quarter, becoming the first team since 2007 to reverse a 18-point lead after three quarters. Second-year quarterback Bo Nix led a dramatic comeback, throwing two touchdowns and rushing for two, culminating in a game-winning field goal. Meanwhile, New England Patriots’ rookie quarterback Drake Maye set a franchise record with a 91.3% completion rate, surpassing Tom Brady’s 88.5% mark, and achieved a historic Super Bowl-era milestone. On the other hand, the Miami Dolphins and New York Jets suffered devastating losses, with quarterbacks Tua Tagovailoa and Justin Fields benched due to poor performances. The Jets’ head coach Aaron Glenn cited the need for a 'spark' in the team’s offensive struggles, while the Dolphins' coach Mike McDaniel faced mounting pressure after Tagovailoa’s three-interception game. The Packers also emerged victorious, with defensive standout Micah Parsons recording a critical sack on Arizona’s final drive. The season continues to highlight dramatic comebacks, record-breaking performances, and personnel changes as key themes.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
